{it}Jesus Christ, Christ{/it}, and {it}Jesus{/it} are commonly used as interjections to express surprise and anger. These uses are avoided in polite speech.

shortdef: the man who Christians believe is the son of God and whose life, death, and resurrection as reported in the New Testament of the Bible are the basis of the Christian religion —called also Jesus

def: {bc} the benefit of someone or something

dt: used in phrases with {it}for{/it} to say that something is done to help a particular person or thing

dt.t: Please do it {it}for her sake{/it}. [=do it for her; do it to help her]
They sacrificed their lives {it}for all our sakes{/it}. [=to help all of us]
We must do it {it}for the sake of{/it} our country.

dt: used in phrases with {it}for{/it} to say that something is done for a particular purpose or to achieve a particular goal or result

dt.t: {it}For simplicity's sake{/it} [=to make this discussion simpler], we'll consider these two options as basically the same.

Let's assume, {it}for argument's sake{/it}, that it was a mistake. = Let's assume, {it}for the sake of{/it} argument, that it was a mistake. [=let's say for now that it was a mistake so that we can see how that will affect our discussion]
{it}For the sake of{/it} clarity [=in order to be clear], I've listed each item separately.
They'll do anything {it}for the sake of{/it} (making a) profit.
scholars who pursue knowledge {it}for its own sake{/it} [=because they want to learn]
I don't paint for money. My motto is {ldquo}{phrase}Art for art's sake{/phrase}.{rdquo} [=I believe in making art for no other reason than that art is important]

dt: used in phrases with {it}for{/it} to express anger, annoyance, surprise, etc.

dt.t: {phrase}For heaven's/Pete's sake{/phrase}, could you hurry up?
Stop asking me questions, {phrase}for God's sake{/phrase}!
{phrase}For pity's/God's/Christ's sake{/phrase}, what's taking so long?
{ldquo}You won!{rdquo} {ldquo}Oh, {phrase}for goodness'/heaven's/Pete's sake{/phrase}. I can't believe it!{rdquo}

dt: The use of {it}God{/it} and {it}Christ{/it} in these phrases is offensive to some people.
If you do something {it}for old times' sake{/it}, you do it because you did it in the past and you want to experience it again.

dt.t: He and his old friends from college went back to the bar {it}for old times' sake{/it}.
We drove around town just {it}for the sake of it{/it}.
